properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The major winter storm continues today. A very moist Pacific frontal system will remain stalled over the coastal passes today and tonight giving continued heavy wet snow near the summits. The snow will be mixed with rain at times today. Further snowfall accumulations are uncertain due to how wet the snow is. Amounts of more than a foot are possible by Thursday morning. The snow will finally end Thursday morning as the system moves out of the region. ### Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-03T05:46:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-02T13:47:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4098922587.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp, South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Easterly winds gusting up to 90 kilometres per hour are expected over Umiujaq today. Wind will ease this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected to develop tonight. Strong winds with blowing snow are expected to develop late this afternoon. Falling snow with very strong winds will cause a blizzard to develop overnight tonight, and last until Friday afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-03T04:00:27-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Multi-day snowfall event continues tonight into Wednesday. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 cm are possible tonight through Wednesday morning. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec tonight into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area Wednesday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall: 40 to 55 mm. Locations: Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: this afternoon to Thursday morning. Remarks: Drizzle or showers will change to rain, at times heavy, this afternoon. Heavy rain will then persist tonight before tapering off Thursday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-03T06:19:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-02T14:20:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0472965358.2020
Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions with very strong gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected to develop early this evening. Strong gusty winds with blowing snow will develop this afternoon. The winds will strengthen with a blizzard developing this evening and lasting until Friday afternoon. Very strong damaging winds will accompany the blizzard. The strongest winds will occur from early Thursday morning until late Thursday afternoon with wind gusts as high as 110 km/h possible. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to widespread poor visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-03T03:58:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-02T11:59:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3339895533.2020
Area: Ulukhaktok

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds and blowing snow Thursday to Friday morning. Winds will increase significantly on Thursday with gusts near 60 km/h expected by mid-day and increasing to near 80 km/h by the evening. These strong winds will cause low visibility in blowing snow. By Thursday evening, the addition of falling snow will likely bring blizzard conditions Thursday overnight into Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
